item.title: ‘Fast Car’ Changed Luke Combs’s Life. He’s Back for More Hits.
item.description: The country singer helped to usher the genre into the streaming era before taking a step back. On his new album, he wants to go for broke.
item.dc:creator: Joe Coscarelli, Jon Caramanica and Jason Nocito
item.media:credit: Jason Nocito for The New York Times

item.title: Melissa Auf der Maur, a ’90s Rock Linchpin, Is Spilling Her Stories
item.description: The bassist and photographer who logged time in Hole and Smashing Pumpkins unpacks one of the most creative and chaotic times of her life in a new memoir.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik and Lucia Bell-Epstein
item.category: Even the Good Girls Will Cry: A '90s Rock Memoir (Book)
item.media:credit: Lucia Bell-Epstein for The New York Times

item.title: What Belongs in America’s 250th Birthday Time Capsule?
item.description: The federal group organizing the upcoming Semiquincentennial unveiled details of a vessel to be placed near Independence Hall on July 4 and opened in 2276.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Gavin Zeigler/Alamy
item.media:description: The Bicentennial of 1976 set off a craze for time capsules, like this one in Bridgehampton, N.Y., to be opened in 2076.

item.title: Noguchi Envisioned a More Open New York. New York Wasn’t Interested.
item.description: Isamu Noguchi became one of the most successful artists of the 20th century, but the city met his plans for public spaces with indifference.
item.dc:creator: Max Lakin

item.title: ‘Scream 7’ Review: Neve Campbell Returns to Face Ghostface
item.description: Ghostface has returned amid a light fog of nostalgia in this reunion for some of the franchise’s most terrified faces, including Neve Campbell’s.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Megan Thee Stallion to Step Into Broadway’s ‘Moulin Rouge! The Musical’
item.description: For eight weeks this spring, the popular rapper will be featured as a nightclub impresario in “Moulin Rouge! The Musical.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’ve always believed in pushing myself creatively,” Megan Thee Stallion, who has three Grammys, said in a statement.

item.title: With Bends, Crinkles and a Cool Decor Makeover, Carol Bove Takes the Guggenheim
item.description: She extracts something new from steel, dispelling its aura of brawn. Her signature form is a rumpled ribbon of metal painted to look as soft as suede.
item.dc:creator: Deborah Solomon and Myrthe Giesbers
item.media:credit: Myrthe Giesbers for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Grease 2,’ the Giddy, Raunchy Flop That Brought Us Michelle Pfeiffer
item.description: The highly anticipated 1982 sequel failed to meet expectations at the time but has since charmed an adoring following with its ambitious dance numbers and nonstop ear worms.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: Tracey Emin on Love, Loss and Getting Out of ‘My Bed’
item.description: Since the artist was diagnosed with aggressive bladder cancer in 2020, a lot has changed in her life and work. A new show at Tate Modern examines Tracey Emin’s “second life.”
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Stanford and Alice Zoo For The New York Times
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times

item.title: Review: Aya Ogawa’s ‘Meat Suit’ Sits With the Mess of Motherhood
item.description: In Aya Ogawa’s compassionate, sharply comical play, the pastel-pink public image of mommyhood doesn’t stand a chance.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes

item.title: ‘In the Blink of an Eye’ Review: We Are the Future
item.description: These three connected stories about the whole of human history can’t quite sustain the necessary emotional heft.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: In the Blink of an Eye (Movie)

item.title: Delroy Lindo on ‘Sinners,’ the Oscars and the Power of Affirmation
item.description: In a career of standout performances and dispiriting lows, Lindo, 73, has held firm to his goal: “I want to be respected for my work.”
item.dc:creator: Clarissa Cruz and Marcus Maddox
item.media:credit: Marcus Maddox for The New York Times

item.title: Gathering Force in the Art Market: Female Collectors
item.description: With women now controlling more than one-third of global wealth, they are spending more on art than men do, data shows, and influencing what museums acquire.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Poppy Lynch for The New York Times
item.media:description: The collector Komal Shah in her home in Atherton, Calif., with the painting, “Todos Os Seres São de Todos Os Seres (All Beings are of All Beings),” 2023, by Sophia Loeb.

item.title: In ‘Mother Russia,’ Lauren Yee Raucously Examines a Shifting Post-Soviet Society
item.description: Lauren Yee’s boisterous play “Mother Russia,” about the origins of the contemporary oligarchy, has its roots in her San Francisco childhood.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I love knowing how things came to be and why people are where they are, how societies have formed,” said the playwright Lauren Yee.

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2, Episode 8 Recap: Unplugged
item.description: Without internet, the Pitt was even more chaotic than usual. This on a national holiday on which people blow up things for fun.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:credit: Warrick Page/HBO Max
item.media:description: Nurse Princess (Kristin Villanueva) had to cover for Dana as the charge nurse for a while. Then the internet went out.

item.title: Jean Widmer, Designer of Celebrated French Graphics, Dies at 96
item.description: His minimalist road signs became a visual hallmark of France’s highways. He also created logos for cultural institutions like the Pompidou Center.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Netflix Backs Out of Bid for Warner Bros., Paving Way for Paramount Takeover
item.description: The move was a stunning development in the long-running corporate battle for the storied media giant.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch, Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount Pictures in Hollywood.

item.title: Teresa de Lauretis, Coiner (and Critic) of Queer Theory, Dies at 87
item.description: She came up with the term as the title of a 1990 conference but saw its later popularity as a little superficial.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:credit: Claudia Peppel
item.media:description: Teresa de Lauretis in 2015. The debut of “queer theory” as a term came in the title of an academic conference she organized and in an associated issue of a feminist journal.

item.title: Rose Lesniak, Poet Who Rescued Children and Trained Dogs, Dies at 70
item.description: A magnetic personality, she reinvented herself twice, bringing the same spirit to investigating child abuse and communing with dogs that she did to writing poetry.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: ‘The Luckiest Man in America’ and More Streaming Gems
item.description: A game-show drama and a documentary valentine to a cult movie queen are among the little treats tucked away on your subscription streaming services this month.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey

item.title: ‘K-Pops!’ Review: Reconnecting Through Music
item.description: Anderson .Paak directs and stars alongside his real-life son in this film, which offers sometimes charming, if somewhat sterile pleasures.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Idiotka’ Review: She’s a Haute Mess
item.description: A scrappy Russian American seamstress from West Hollywood competes in a fashion design reality show in this clever and earnest indie comedy.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: ‘Ghost Elephants’ Review: Pursuing What Could Be a Dream
item.description: Werner Herzog’s new documentary about the hunt for elephants in Angola focuses less on the animals and more on the pursuers.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: ‘Dreams’ Review: Erotic, but Not Enough Charge
item.description: Jessica Chastain plays a wealthy philanthropist obsessed with an undocumented dancer in this chilly drama.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: Late Night Fixates on How Long Trump Spoke
item.description: “This time, Trump spoke and everyone else fell asleep,” Jimmy Fallon said.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Ann Godoff, a Top Editor and Publisher of Best Sellers, Dies at 76
item.description: Considered an “author’s publisher” at Random House and then Penguin, she cultivated the careers of dozens of celebrated novelists and nonfiction writers.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Librado Romero/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ann Godoff at the Random House offices in Manhattan in 1999 with the editor Robert Loomis. She had “a flawless sense of what would sell and what wouldn’t,” the biographer Ron Chernow said.

item.title: Lauren Chapin, Youngest Child on ‘Father Knows Best,’ Dies at 80
item.description: For six seasons, she was Kathy, a giggly tomboy whose father, played by Robert Young, called her Kitten. Her offscreen life, however, was harrowing.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates

item.title: Three Great Frederick Wiseman Documentaries to Stream
item.description: This month offers a tribute to the prolific filmmaker who died last week at 96 and has a plausible claim to being the greatest documentarian who ever lived.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: Resident Evil Requiem Shines Within Its Confines
item.description: The corridors of a former sanitarium are both terrifying and rewarding, while Raccoon City is bland and filled with chores.
item.dc:creator: Yussef Cole

item.title: A Seasoned French Museum Chief Takes Over a Louvre in Crisis
item.description: Christophe Leribault, who runs the Palace of Versailles, will replace Laurence des Cars, who resigned months after an audacious jewel heist.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christophe Leribault was the deputy director of the Louvre’s graphic arts department from 2006 to 2012 and has run three other museums, in addition to the one at Versailles.

item.title: Phil Collins, Wu-Tang Clan and Lauryn Hill Are Among Rock Hall of Fame Nominees
item.description: Jeff Buckley, Lauryn Hill, New Edition and INXS are also included on the ballot for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.category: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum
item.media:credit: Clemens Bilan/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Phil Collins performing in June 2019.

item.title: ‘Modern Love’: I Didn’t Want to Have Kids. My Husband Did. Could Our Marriage Survive?
item.description: Helena de Groot thought she had decided not to become a mother. But, she found, she had to make that decision over and over again.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Sara Curtis, Elisa Gutierrez, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Carole Sabouraud and Pat McCusker
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Background: Brian Rea; Inset photo: John Lamparski/Getty Images for Tribeca Festival

item.title: Watch Renate Reinsve Struggle With Stage Fright in ‘Sentimental Value’
item.description: The director Joachim Trier narrates a theatrical sequence from his film, nominated for nine Academy Awards, including best picture.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy
item.media:credit: Kasper Tuxen/Neon, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Renate Reinsve in “Sentimental Value.”

item.title: ‘Days and Nights in the Forest’: Into the Woods With Satyajit Ray
item.description: In a new 4K restoration of this 1970 Indian classic, four upper-caste men travel for an adventure, with their entitlement taking a starring role.
item.dc:creator: J. Hoberman
item.category: Days and Nights in the Forest (Movie)
item.media:credit: Janus Films
item.media:description: A still from Satyajit Ray’s 1970 film, “Days and Nights in the Forest.” From left, Subhendu Chatterjee, Samit Bhanja, Soumitra Chatterjee and Rabi Ghosh.

item.title: What Do They Eat at Awards Shows (and Why Do We Care)?
item.description: Interest has surged in what stars are served at shows like the Golden Globes. Does it matter what the rich eat, or do we just want to eat the rich?
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The New York International Children’s Film Festival
item.description: Indigenous peoples, interspecies friendships, space travel and a history-making young paleontologist are on the bill for this annual event.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Graeber
item.category: New York International Childrens Film Festival

item.title: ‘The Bluff’ Review: She Has a Very Particular Set of Skills
item.description: Priyanka Chopra Jonas plays a notorious pirate who must protect her family at all costs in this Caribbean action movie.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: Podcasts? TV Talk Shows? Netflix Just Hopes They’re Hits.
item.description: The podcasts in the streamer’s debut crop, including “The Pete Davidson Show,” have revived metaphysical questions about the definition of the medium.
item.dc:creator: Reggie Ugwu
item.category: The White House With Michael Irvin (TV Program)

item.title: ‘Sentimental Value’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The director Joachim Trier narrates a sequence from his film.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy
item.media:credit: Kasper Tuxen/Neon, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Renate Reinsve in “Sentimental Value.”

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Goes Live After a Super Long State of the Union
item.description: “I can’t believe America missed an all-new ‘Will Trent’ for this one,” he joked.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Éliane Radigue, Composer of Time, Silence and Space, Dies at 94
item.description: Her Tibetan Buddhist spiritual practice and her experiments with synthesizers came together in vast, slow-moving works that drew wide acclaim.
item.dc:creator: Peter Catapano
item.media:credit: Aude Paget/INA, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Éliane Radigue in 2011. Her subtly shifting textures seemed to ebb and flow glacially, without the sense of forward motion or drama that has characterized much of Western music.

item.title: ‘Heated Rivalry’ Author Says Parkinson’s Symptoms Are Worsening and Delays Book
item.description: Rachel Reid told fans that the disease’s progression was slowing her writing and that a much-anticipated follow-up book would be pushed back.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Carolina Andrade for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reid published in 2018 the first novel in the series, “Game Changer,” about a closeted hockey player who fell in love with a barista.

item.title: 6 (More) Albums I’m Looking Forward to in 2026
item.description: Hear anticipated new music from Lana Del Rey, Grace Ives, Yaya Bey and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Nicky J Sims/Getty Images
item.media:description: Lana Del Rey

item.title: Review: ‘You Got Older,’ With Alia Shawkat, Gets a Sharp Revival
item.description: Clare Barron’s gorgeous play, about an unmoored young woman returning home to care for her father, finds a new home at Cherry Lane Theater.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Alia Shawkat and Peter Friedman in Clare Barron’s “You Got Older” at the Cherry Lane Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: International Booker Prize Nominees: 13 Books to Get You Talking
item.description: Novels by Daniel Kehlmann, Olga Ravn and Gabriela Cabezón Cámara are among the 13 titles nominated for the renowned award for fiction translated into English.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Robert Carradine, Actor Who Played the Father in ‘Lizzie McGuire,’ Dies at 71
item.description: A member of a renowned acting dynasty, he also earned fame for his role in “Revenge of the Nerds.” His family said he struggled with bipolar disorder.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Ron Galella Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Robert Carradine in 1992. His biggest film success came in 1984 with “Revenge of the Nerds.”

item.title: Russell Brand Pleads Not Guilty to Further Rape and Sexual Assault Charges
item.description: The YouTuber, actor and comedian had already pleaded not guilty to five other charges of sexual assault in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Toby Melville/Reuters
item.media:description: The actor and comedian Russell Brand arriving at court in London on Tuesday.

item.title: Gustavo Dudamel’s Long Goodbye to L.A., and Long Hello to New York
item.description: As the conductor prepares to leave the Los Angeles Philharmonic for the New York Philharmonic, he says, “I am in two waters.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: Jake Michaels for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gustavo Dudamel, who is leaving the Los Angeles Philharmonic this summer and taking over as the music and artistic director of the New York Philharmonic in September.

item.title: For Lee Krasner and Jackson Pollock, Equal Footing at the Met
item.description: Krasner was typecast as the wife of the breakout artist of the Abstract Expressionist movement, no matter how renegade her own work. At the Met this fall, she emerges from his giant shadow.
item.dc:creator: Amei Wallach

item.title: Reanimal Is a Modern-Day Fairy Tale About Cycles of Trauma
item.description: Reanimal puts children in perilous circumstances, a familiar theme for the studio behind Little Nightmares.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Byrd

item.title: A Chimney in Search of a Home Lands 3,000 Miles Away
item.description: Kelly Akashi, an artist, was one of thousands who lost their houses in last winter’s Eaton wildfire in Los Angeles. Her new sculpture for the Whitney Biennial marks one year of slow recovery.
item.dc:creator: Travis Diehl
item.media:credit: Adali Schell for The New York Times
item.media:description: The artist Kelly Akashi searches through the rubble of her Altadena home and studio in June for artworks that survived. Her home was one of thousands lost between January’s various fires throughout the city.

item.title: Dance Reflections Returns With Bumps but a Thrilling Ride
item.description: Dance Reflections, a festival that pushes contemporary dance brought performances to Manhattan and Brooklyn last weekend.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas

item.title: Anne Frank’s Love for Classical Music L Her Diary
item.description: Her diary overflows with her devotion to books and movies. But after rereading the entries, a critic was struck by how often she writes about music.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Tommasini
item.media:credit: Photo 12/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images

item.title: Late Night Sums Up Trump’s Tariff Tiff with the Supreme Court
item.description: “Wow, a court composed mostly of his own party’s appointees has struck down the constitutionality of Trump’s go-it-alone tariff regime,” Jon Stewart said. “That’s bound to cause him some introspection.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Have I Got News for You (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: ‘Mother Russia’ Review: A New Play That’s as Funny as It’s Smart
item.description: A strong cast stars in Lauren Yee’s new play, part of a cycle of works about the collisions between 20th-century communism, capitalism and pop culture.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steven Boyer as Dmitri and Adam Chanler-Berat as Evgeny getting a taste of capitalism in Lauren Yee’s “Mother Russia” at the Signature Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: A Wake for The Washington Post’s Book World
item.description: Literary and cultural denizens of the nation’s capital gathered on Saturday to eulogize The Post’s scuppered Book World supplement.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Dirda, a longtime book critic at The Washington Post, honors the paper’s books section, which was shuttered earlier this month amid widespread layoffs.

item.title: Jeff and Lauren Sánchez Bezos Will Be Honorary Chairs of the Met Gala
item.description: The news came tucked into the second page of a recent news release.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos and Lauren Sánchez Bezos at a Kering Foundation gala in New York in September.

item.title: Edward Hoagland, Literary Explorer of Nature and Himself, Dies at 93
item.description: In his lyrical writings, he examined physical landscapes as well as the interior terrain of his own life — up to the blindness that overtook him in his later years.
item.dc:creator: Margalit Fox
item.media:credit: Oscar White/Corbis, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Edward Hoagland, best known for writing about the natural world, travel and his own life, was, John Updike said, “the best essayist of my generation.”

item.title: The Never-Ending Trial of Tyra Banks
item.description: A new docuseries has renewed criticism of the supermodel-turned-TV mogul. It’s just one cost of her barrier-breaking career.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips
item.category: Reality Check: Inside America's Next Top Model (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Netflix
item.media:description: Tyra Banks sitting for an interview in “Reality Check: Inside America’s Next Top Model.”

item.title: Nick Reiner Pleads Not Guilty in the Killing of His Parents
item.description: Mr. Reiner, 32, was charged with murdering his parents, the Hollywood director Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner, last year.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Chris Torres
item.media:description: Nick Reiner waived his right to a speedy trial on Monday, two months after he was charged with first-degree murder.

item.title: BAFTAs Guest With Tourettes Shouts Racial Slur During Michael B. Jordan and Delroy Lindo’s Appearance
item.description: A racist slur, shouted involuntarily while Michael B. Jordan and Delroy Lindo were presenting an award, raised questions about how the show’s host and the BBC responded.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:credit: Stuart Wilson/Getty Images for BAFTA

item.title: ‘Survivor’ Is America
item.description: It’s our greatest game and our truest mirror. And in its tiki-torch-festooned way, it’s captured our society as an ever-changing collection of tribes.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
